spanishExample: ¡Vámonos! No *we know* a estos chicos.
englishTranslation: Let’s leave! We don’t know these guys.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: ¡Vamos! ¡No es para nada *boring!*
englishTranslation: Let’s go! It isn’t at all boring!

spanishExample: ¡Váyase porque es *dangerous!*
englishTranslation: (Formal) Leave because it’s dangerous!

spanishExample: ¡Vete ahora! Tenemos cosas de más.
englishTranslation: Leave now! We have extra things.

spanishExample: *Back then* uno tenía que hacer esas cosas.
englishTranslation: Back then one had to do those things.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: El otro chico tiene una de esas cosas.
englishTranslation: The other boy has one of those things.

spanishExample: Esas cosas están de más.
englishTranslation: Those things are extra.

spanishExample: Esta casa es mejor porque tiene de todo.
englishTranslation: This house is better because it has a bit of everything.
vocabIncluded: tiene de todo: "has some of everything" (idiom)

spanishExample: Hay que hacer muchas cosas.
englishTranslation: There is a need to make many things.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

spanishExample: Los chicos tendrán que hacer eso.
englishTranslation: The boys will have to do that.
vocabIncluded: tendrán: "will have", "they will have" (Tener, future, 3rd person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No es así para nada.
englishTranslation: It’s not that way at all.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"

spanishExample: No está de más si los dos están aquí.
englishTranslation: It couldn’t hurt if both are here.
vocabIncluded: no está de más: "it couldn't hurt" (idiom)

spanishExample: No está de más *to visit the city* porque tiene de todo.
englishTranslation: It couldn’t hurt to visit the city because it has a bit of everything.
vocabIncluded: no está de más: "it couldn't hurt" (idiom)
tiene de todo: "has some of everything" (idiom)

spanishExample: No tenemos que hacer lo que *you say.*
englishTranslation: We don’t have to do what you say.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Ten dos *books* para que yo tenga tres.
englishTranslation: Have two books, so that I have three.

spanishExample: Tendrá que hacer esto cuando ellos vayan a su casa.
englishTranslation: He will have to do this when they go to his house.
vocabIncluded: tendrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" (Tener, future, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que *bring drinks* en vez de *food.*
englishTranslation: You have to bring drinks instead of food.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Váyanse o en vez de eso *I will call the police.*
englishTranslation: (All of you) Leave or instead of that I will call the police.

spanishExample: Ve al lugar y *I hope* que no tengas *trouble.*
englishTranslation: Go to the place and I hope you don’t have trouble.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al: "to the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: Voy a *face* a mis *enemies* otra vez.
englishTranslation: I’m going to face my enemies again.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
